Okay, this seems to take just the type of NO_LOCATION_PREFERENCE. Internally, it will keep all elements.

Yeah, it is odd how this API works, but when you pass in an array with fewer elements than you need, it will allocate a new one for you that is the right size. So we pass in a 0-element array. If you just call toArray, Java won't get the type right. The streams API allows passing in an array constructor (String[]::new), but it seems awkward to create a stream when there's already a working, although awkward, API call for it.

Should we use TableCatalog.PROP_LOCATION? What about comment, owner? I recall some bug fixes in Spark but will need to check again as I forgot the context.
I'll double-check these.

Updated to use PROP_LOCATION. While comment and owner are reserved properties in Spark, but Iceberg tracks these as table properties.
Side note: we have a class to sync some table properties into other metadata fields in our metastore implementation. But the Iceberg API doesn't explicitly track all of them. I think it makes sense to use table properties here.
Makes sense.

Does it mean ALTER TABLE t SET TBLPROPERTIES can be used for rollbacks and cherry-picking? Will it make sense to build dedicated SQL commands for such operations and plugin via session extensions? I know it is much easier to do this via SET TBLPROPERTIES but I am not sure how natural it is.
Yes, this is what we do to expose cherry-picking and setting the current snapshot explicitly through SQL. I can remove it if there are objections to this.

These are very valuable features. Internally, we offer a SQL command to rollback tables. We don't expose cherry-picking yet but we are really excited about this feature. Do we want to have some SQL commands directly in Iceberg? I'd vote for that. It probably makes sense to agree on the syntax for common operations and use that across all query engines and all teams. For example, we can start with SNAPSHOT, MIGRATE, a command to rollback and a command to cherry-pick changes. These are easy to agree on. Later, we can build a VACUUM command that can optimize the table state. This one will be harder but we can add it later.
If that's something that we want to build, I can create a proposal in a couple of days.
I'd love to see standardization here.

In which cases will we both update props and modify schema?

I originally proposed a public API for updating tables, which could batch operations together into a group:
Table updated = spark.catalog("prod")
    .updateTable("name")
    .addColumn("z", "bigint")
    .renameColumn("a", "x")
    .set("prop", "value")
I think it makes sense to assume that this may happen. We could also receive direct calls through the catalog API.
